facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1053 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1053 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 29, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 249 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 29, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 249 of 1962.

facts.text: Certificate granted by the High Court of Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Allahabad

facts.text: Appellant was in the service of the State of Uttar Pradesh as Sub-Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was in the service of the State of Uttar Pradesh as Sub-Registrar.

facts.text: Appellant was born on December 11, 1905.

anchor.surface_text: He was born on December 11, 1905 and was recruited in service in July 1933.

facts.text: Appellant was recruited in service in July 1933.

anchor.surface_text: and was recruited in service in July 1933.

facts.text: At the time of recruitment, age of retirement for government servants of his class was 55 years.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of his recruitment the age of retirement or superannuation for government servants of his class was 55 years.

facts.text: Normally, appellant should have retired on December 11, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, normally he should have retired on December 11, 1960.

facts.text: Government of Uttar Pradesh issued notification dated November 27, 1957 raising age of retirement to 58 years.

anchor.surface_text: But by a notification dated November 27, 1957, the Government of Uttar Pradesh hereinafter referred to as the Government raised the age of retirement or superannuation to 58 years.

facts.text: After 1957 notification, appellant would have retired on December 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: This meant that the appellant would have retired on December 11, 1963.

facts.text: On May 25, 1961, Government reduced age of retirement to 55 years by notification under Art. 309.

anchor.surface_text: On May 25, 1961, the Government again reduced the age of retirement or superannuation to 55 years by a notification of that date issued under Art. 309 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Proviso added to rules deeming certain servants retained beyond 55 years.

anchor.surface_text: Further a proviso was added in the rules relating to retirement in these terms Provided that a Government servant who had not retired on or before June 17, 1957 but has subsequently attained the age of 55 years and has on May 25, 1961 not attained the age of 58 years shall, for the period he has continued to serve after attaining the age of 55 years be deemed to have been retained in service beyond the date of compulsory retirement, i.e., the age of 55 years within the meaning of the Rule aforesaid.

facts.text: Another order issued by Governor on May 25, 1961 directing retention per Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Further as this change in the age of retirement would have resulted in immediate retirement of all government servants above the age of 55 years with consequent dislocation of public service, another order was issued by the Governor on the same day directing that any government servant who had on or before the date of the order already been directed in pursuance of the proviso set out above to be retained beyond the age of compulsory retirement or superannuation shall be so retained in accordance with the Schedule attached to the order.

facts.text: Schedule provided retention for servants over 57 years on May 25, 1961 up to 58 years or Dec 31, 1961 whichever earlier.

anchor.surface_text: This Schedule provided that- Government servants who had on May 25, 1961 crossed the age of 57 years were to be retained up to the date on which they attained the age of 58 years or up to December 31, 1961 whichever was earlier

facts.text: Servants aged 55-57 on May 25, 1961 retained up to Dec 31, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Government servants who had on May 25, 1961 crossed the age of 55 years but had not crossed the age of 57 years were to be retained up to December 31,1961

facts.text: Servants crossing 55 between May 25 and Dec 30, 1961 retained to Dec 31, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: and Government servants, who would cross the age of 55 years between May 25, 1961 and December 30, 1961 were to be retained up to December 31, 1961.

facts.text: Appellant retired on December 31, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: In consequence of this order, the appellant who had crossed the age of 55 years before May 25, 1961 but had not crossed the age of 57 years was retired on December 31, 1961,

facts.text: Appellant had crossed age of 55 before May 25, 1961 but not 57 years.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant who had crossed the age of 55 years before May 25, 1961 but had not crossed the age of 57 years

facts.text: Ram Autar Pandey filed writ petition challenging reduction in retirement age.

anchor.surface_text: This reduction in the age of retirement led to a writ petition by one Ram Autar Pandey in the High Court challenging the power of Government to reduce the age of retirement.

facts.text: Ram Autar Pandey petition dismissed by Full Bench of Allahabad High Court on December 21, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: That petition was heard by a Full Bench of the Allahabad High Court and was dismissed on December 21, 1961 see Ram Autar Pandey v. State of U.P.

facts.text: Present petition filed on December 4, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The petition out of which the present appeal has arisen was filed on December 4, 1961

facts.text: Present petition dismissed on March 29, 1962 following Ram Autar Pandey case.

anchor.surface_text: and was dismissed on March 29, 1962 following the decision in Ram Autar Pandeys case.

facts.text: Appeal to Division Bench dismissed on same basis.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon there was an appeal to the Division Bench which was also dismissed on the same basis.

facts.text: Application for leave to appeal to Supreme Court granted.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed an application for leave to appeal to this Court which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us.

facts.text: Proviso refers to government servants who had not retired on or before June 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that a Government servant who had not retired on or before June 17, 1957

facts.text: Appellant remained in service after December 11, 1960 due to 1957 rule.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant got the advantage of that inasmuch as he remained in service after December 11, 1960 on which date he would have otherwise retired on completing the age of 55 years.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Deka v. General Manager, North Frontier Railway 1 . That case dealt with a rule in the Railway Code giving power to the Railway Administration to ter

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule concerns superannuation age reduction, not removal; Moti Ram Deka distinguished as it did not deal with retirement age rules and itself held superannuation termination not removal under Art. 311; no provision bars government from altering superannuation age under Art. 309.

arguments.claim: Reliance in this connection has been placed on Moti Ram Deka v. General Manager, North Frontier Railway to argue termination amounts to removal under Art. 311

anchor.surface_text: within the meaning of Art. 311. Reliance in this connection has been placed on Moti Ram Deka v. General Manager, North Frontier Railway. That case dealt with a rule in the Railway Code giving power to the Railway Administration to terminate the services of all permanent servants to whom the rule applied merely on giving notice for a specified period or on payment of salary in lieu thereof at any time during the service long before the age of retirement.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f Art. 311 2 . That case in our opinion has numberapplication to the facts of the present case, for that case did number deal with any rule relating t

arguments.court_reasoning: Moti Ram Deka not applicable as it did not concern retirement age rules; that case clarified superannuation or compulsory retirement rules do not amount to removal.

arguments.claim: The rule in question being retrospective was bad as notification could be made retrospectively

anchor.surface_text: The rule in question being retrospective was bad as notification could be made retrospectively and The rule was hit by Art. 14 inasmuch as it resulted in inequality between public servants in the matter of retirement.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule purely prospective from May 25, 1961; proviso deems prior service beyond 55 as retention under prior rule; second order retained all until Dec 31, 1961 or 58 to avoid dislocation; no retirements before notification date.

arguments.claim: The rule was hit by Art. 14 inasmuch as it resulted in inequality between public servants in the matter of retirement

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rule was applied retrospectively. We have already referred to the proviso which lays down that government servants who had attained the age of 55 year

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule fixes uniform age of 55 and same retirement date Dec 31, 1961 for all over 55 under 58; differences in actual retirement age arise from prior retentions necessary for public service exigencies and efficiency, not arbitrariness.

arguments.claim: A rule as to superannuation or compulsory retirement shortly before superannuation resulting in termination does not amount to removal under Art. 311

anchor.surface_text: Further it was made clear in that very case that a rule as to superannuation retirement or as to compulsory retirement shortly before the age of superannuation resulting in the termination of service of a public servant did not amount to removal.

arguments.claim: No provision takes away the power of government to increase or reduce the age of superannuation

anchor.surface_text: We have not been shown any provision which takes away the power of government to increase, or reduce the age of superannuation and therefore as the rule in question only dealt with the age of superannuation and the appellant had to retire because of the reduction in the age of superannuation

arguments.claim: Art. 311 has no application to the termination of service of the appellant in the present case

anchor.surface_text: Art. 311 has no application to the termination of service of the appellant in the present case.

arguments.claim: The proviso does not make the rule retrospective; it provides how period of service beyond 55 years should be treated

anchor.surface_text: The next contention on behalf of the appellant is that the rule is retrospective and that no retrospective rule can be made. As we read the rule we do not find any retrospectivity in it. [...] This proviso in our opinion does not make the rule retrospective it only provides as to how the period of service beyond 55 years should be treated in view of the earlier rule of 1957 which was being changed by the rule of 1961.

arguments.claim: The new rule reducing age from 58 to 55 cannot be said to be retrospective; proviso and second notification tide over dislocation and financial issues

anchor.surface_text: Further the second order issued on the same day also clearly shows that there was no retrospective operation of the rule for in actual effect no government servant was retired before the date of the new rule i.e., May 25, 1961 [...] The proviso to the new rule and the second notification are only methods to tide over the difficult situation which would arise in the public service if the new rule was applied at once and also to meet any financial objection arising out of the enforcement of the new rule.

arguments.claim: The new rule is not discriminatory; it fixes uniform retirement age of 55 years and same date Dec 31, 1961 for affected servants

anchor.surface_text: The last argument that has been urged is that the new rule is discriminatory as different public servants have in effect been retired at different ages. We see no force in this contention either, retirement namely December 31, 1961 in the case of all public servants and fixes the age of retirement at 55 years. There is no discrimination in the rule itself.

arguments.claim: Differences in retirement ages due to retention after 55 depend on efficiency and exigencies of public service, not discriminatory

anchor.surface_text: But this was not because they retired at different ages but because their services were retained for different periods after the age of fifty-five. Now it cannot be urged that if Government decides to retain the services of some public servants after the age of retirement it must retain every public servant for the same length of time. The retention of public servants after the period of retirement depends upon their efficiency and the exigencies of Public service

arguments.claim: Government has power to reduce the age of retirement (as challenge dismissed)

anchor.surface_text: This reduction in the age of retirement led to a writ petition by one Ram Autar Pandey in the High Court challenging the power of Government to reduce the age of retirement. That petition was heard by a Full Bench of the Allahabad High Court and was dismissed on December 21, 1961

arguments.court_reasoning: Present petition and appeal dismissed following Ram Autar Pandey decision.

holdings.text: Art. 311 has no application to the termination of service of the appellant in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 311 has no application to the termination of service of the appellant in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule reducing superannuation age does not constitute removal under Art. 311; Moti Ram Deka distinguished as not concerning retirement age rules, which terminate service without invoking Art. 311 protections; no statutory bar to altering superannuation age under Art. 309.

holdings.text: the new rule reducing the age of retirement from 58 years to 55 years cannot be said to be retrospective. The proviso to the new rule and the second notification are only methods to tide over the difficult situation which would arise in the public service if the new rule was applied at once and also to meet any financial objection arising out of the enforcement of the new rule.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the new rule reducing the, age of retirement from 58 years to 55 years cannot be said to be retrospective. The proviso to the new rule and the second notification are only methods to tide over the difficult situation which would arise in the public service if the new rule was applied at once and also to meet any financial objection arising out of the enforcement of the new rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule operates prospectively from May 25, 1961; proviso deems prior service beyond 55 as retention to align with 1957 rule change; schedule/order prevents immediate retirements and dislocation, confirming no retrospection as no one retired before notification date.

holdings.text: the second notification of may 25,1961 on which reliance is placed to prove discrimination is really not discriminatory for it has treated all public servants alike and fixed December 31, 1961 as the date of retirement for those who had completed 55 years but not 58 years up to December 31, 1961. The challenge therefore, to the two notifications on the basis of Art. 14 must fail.

anchor.surface_text: we are therefore of opinion that the second notification of may 25,1961 on which reliance is placed to prove discrimination is really not discriminatory for it has treated all public servants alike and fixed December 31, 1961 as the date of retirement for-those who had completed 55 years but not 58 years up to December 31, 1961. The challenge therefore, to the, two notifications on the basis of Art. 14 must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule and schedule impose uniform retirement age of 55 and common date Dec 31, 1961 for affected servants (55-58 years); variations in actual age at retirement stem from prior necessary retentions based on efficiency and public service exigencies, not arbitrary discrimination.
